recordings.loc: Grassy Hollow, Angeles National Forest, Los Angeles County, California
recordings.rmk:
Male song recorded at a range of about 30 meters while the bird was perched atop a Jeffrey pine.  We did not hear any flight calls, although every red crossbill flight call recorded in this mountain range to date has been type 2. 

Equipment: Sony PCM-M10 and a Sennheiser ME67.
The sounds of human coughing, voices, a camera clicking, and a jet are also audible.

Flight calls from four birds, listed here as race guillemardi based on location. Sonogram does look rather similar to proposed call-type S3, albeit beginning with a low energy upstroke element. Any comments are welcome.
Flight call type A according to Robb 2000.
Flight call type C according to Robb 2000.
Excitement call type D according to Robb 2000.

recordings.loc: Highway 20, Stop 3, near  Riske Creek, Cariboo, British Columbia
recordings.rmk:
Songs.  We identified the flight call type (3) by ear but it doesn't appear that we were able to get recordings of it.  This particular recording has songs.

Recorded at the edge of a Douglas-fir forest.  Numerous other birds were present and they were all vocal, especially the white-winged crossbills.

Equipment: Sony PCM-M10, Sennheiser ME62, and a Telinga 22 inch parabola.

A human voice is also audible.

recordings.loc: Highway 20, Stop 2, near  Riske Creek, Cariboo, British Columbia
recordings.rmk:
Recorded at the edge of a Douglas-fir forest.  Surrounding areas were open with nearby ponds and streams.

Equipment: Sony PCM-M10, Sennheiser ME62, and a Telinga 22 inch parabola.

Human voices and an approaching vehicle are also audible.

recordings.type: call, flight call, life stage uncertain, sex uncertain
recordings.rmk: flock of 10 birds rustling in leaves then flying and returing

Groove of spruces and pines surrounded by mire, close to a small lake. Adult bird feeding chick. Group of adult and juvenile birds feeding in the vicinity.

0:00-0:35: Intense high-pitched begging call *ti-ti-ti-ti* (series of calls starting at 0:07.1, 0:11) interspersed by adult call *glipp* (e.g. 0:17.6, 0:22.8).
Large flock of type n4 and n8.
Types n3, n4 and n8. Intervals shortened.
Mixpre3 II & Telinga MK2 directed to bird 15 meters away. Full gain 32 bit float file and then normalized in Audition and further edit in Audicity.

recordings.rmk: 2 birds, flight calls,  Type N2. First time I record this type in this forest near Paris. To know more about crossbill types, see https://avesrares.wordpress.com/2019/03/29/call-types-of-crossbills-in-europe/

recordings.loc: National Botanic Garden (near  Salaspils), Salaspils pilsēta, Salaspils Municipality
Grassy Hollow, Angeles National Forest, Los Angeles County, California
recordings.rmk:
Type 2red crossbill songs (from at least two birds) with evening grosbeak type 1 flight calls and other vocalizations  in the background.

Recorded on a hill with Jeffrey pine and white fir.  Some of both species were feedling on Jeffrey pine cone seeds.  There were numerous male red crossbills singing in the area.

Equipment: Sony PCM-M10 and a Sennheiser ME62 equipped with a Telinga 22 inch parabola, hand-held.

recordings.loc: Grassy Hollow, Angeles National Forest, Los Angeles County, California
recordings.rmk:
Type 2red crossbill songs and flight calls with evening grosbeak type 1 flight calls and other vocalizations  in the background.

Recorded on a hill with Jeffrey pine and white fir.  Some of both species were feedling on Jeffrey pine cone seeds.  There were numerous male red crossbills singing in the area.

Equipment: Sony PCM-M10 and a Sennheiser ME62 equipped with a Telinga 22 inch parabola, hand-held.

recordings.loc: Sephu on Bumthang-Ura highway, Wangdue Phodrang
recordings.rmk: Hard to classify sound, extremely soft, and not audible without a parabola microphone, I believe.  Male sitting in pine tree, just looking around and enjoying itself with this soft 3-part whistle which I would render as "uu-wee ee" and which looks like an S in the sonogram.  Occasionally, and intro note added in front : "tew."
Birds not seen but perhaps a flock of 5-6 birds.

Call type C (Robb 2000) or N4 (Rochefort, Martin 2019)

recordings.rmk: migrating birds 20 ind.

Call picked up by unattended parabol that had been left recording from dawn at 03.07am. Recorded on Baltic Coastline in Västerbotten, Sweden. My initial thoughts were that this might be a wader, before the suggestion of Crossbill Sp. was made to me. A little research confirmed the identification

recordings.loc: Bunken Plantage, Hulsig, Frederikshavn Municipality, North Denmark Region
recordings.rmk: Flock of c 30 in spruce trees.

Feeding on ornamental Spruces (Picea pungens). The flock was disturbed by something (as was nearby Red-breasted Nuthatches) and they circled for about a minute before returning to feeding. The recording was made on an Olympus LS10 linear PCM microphone and was high-pass filtered at 1000 Hz with 12 dB/Hz roll-off to eliminate the noise of ventilation from a nearby building. The recording was then normalized so that the maximum volume was -1 dB.

recordings.file-name: XC399164-CROSSBI_Red_c_flight resp NPO No 2 2nd Crest Trail 2700m 102113 1029.mp3
recordings.rmk: now 3 or 4 birds, delayed resp to NPO fuss, starting with flight calls given perched, then took off calling, meanwhile one remaining bird (not an adult male) started giving loud flight calls while perched and stayed perched, eventually going silent; this is recording No 2, 2nd, the prior having perched calls in resp to owl whistles;
brownish, female-plumaged bird with a little mottling underneath, perched then in flight; kinked Type 2;

recordings.loc: Barfoot Park, Chiricahua Mountains, Cochise County, Arizona
recordings.type: alarm call, flight call, interaction calls
recordings.rmk: six birds with large, heavy black bills, large body size, males fairly orangy; fierce interactions between a couple of birds after 0:19; mostly perched, including flight-type calls, but brief flight calls also in short flights; Ida Peak Trail; the first flight call and many in the second half are fine for Type 6, but a couple of really bad ones after 0:02 look like something else, perhaps Type 5??, which would be unusual here; strong wind partly filtered;

recordings.loc: Dechambeau Creek, NW Mono Basin, Mono County, California
recordings.rmk:
A small flock was erratically present for a few days: 7 birds on 5/27, at least 11 this day of recording. High tinny calls different from usual plunky pine types. Were foraging in riparian - apparently eating the leaf bases of Black Cottonwood. Photos are on ebird checklist S35746993. Males I noted were marbled red & brownish of subadults. 
Recording not modified - except it is an excerpt of longer recording

forest near Hagenheim/Hofstetten (near Landsberg), Upper Bavaria, Bavaria
recordings.type: call, flight call, very excited calls
recordings.rmk:
In this winter there are a lot of Crossbills in our region. Today morning I heard in the nearby wood these calls in the top of high spruces.  I am not familiar with the voices of young Crossbills and I first thought, it could be the begging calls of fledged Crossbills. Specially, because I heard long series of these calls in short intervalls. But the discussion in the forum convinced me, that these calls (which I never heard before) are probably exciting calls of adult Crossbills. Mating? Or because a hawk was roaming through the wood?  But why in relatively regular Intervalls? Same place, same situation look at XC304228, XC304229, XC302839.
At 0:19 "normal" flight calls from an adult. 
Weather: relatively warm since long, the spruces have a lot of cones.

recordings.loc: forest near Hagenheim/Hofstetten (near Landsberg), Upper Bavaria, Bavaria
recordings.type: call, flight call, very excited calls
recordings.rmk:
In this winter there are a lot of Crossbills in our region. Today morning I heard in the nearby wood these calls in the top of high spruces. I am not familiar with the voices of young Crossbills and I first thought, it could be the begging calls of two or three fledged Crossbills. Specially, because I heard long series of these calls in short intervalls. But the discussion in the forum convinced me, that these calls (which I never heard before) are probably exciting calls of adult Crossbills. Mating? Or because a hawk was roaming through the wood? But why in relatively regular intervalls? Same place, same situation look at XC304228, XC304230, XC302839. At 0:58 "normal" flight calls from an adult. 
Weather: relatively warm since long, the spruces have a lot of cones.

recordings.loc: Fischener Bucht, shore near Aidenrieder Steg/Ammersee, near Fischen, Landsberg/Lech, Oberbayern, Bayern
recordings.type: male, song, wing sound by flying down at the end
recordings.file-name: XC304227-FICHTENKREUZSCHNABEL  3.01.2016  Fischener Bucht  11_44  VOC_160103-3516 + 17 gült. x.-c.mp3
recordings.rmk: this male Crossbill sang in an tree near the Ammersee-shore, changing its phrase at 1:11, and flew at the end down to the shore. In the following weeks Crossbills were  to hear and see at all visit times, so its nearly sure, that at least one pair of Crossbills breed ore bred in this area

recordings.loc: forest near Hagenheim/Hofstetten (near Landsberg), Upper Bavaria, Bavaria
recordings.type: call, flight call, very excited calls
recordings.file-name: XC302839-FICHTENKREUZSCHNABEL, juv. u. ad.  9.02.2016  HhWald S    11_18  VOC_160209-3621   l..mp3
recordings.rmk:
In this winter there are a lot of Crossbills in our region. Today morning I heard in the nearby wood these calls in the top of high spruces. I am not familiar with the voices of young Crossbills and I first thought, it could be the begging calls of  fledged Crossbills. Specially, because I heard long series of these calls in short intervalls. But the discussion in the forum convinced me, that these calls (which I never heard before) are probably exciting calls of adult Crossbills. Mating? Or because a hawk was roaming through the wood? But why in relatively regular intervalls? Same place, same situation,  look at XC304228, XC304230, XC302829. At 0:07 "normal" flight calls from an adult. 
Weather: relatively warm since long, the spruces have a lot of cones. HPF

recordings.file-name: XC301149-FICHTENENKREUZSCHNABEL, singing in the rain  HhD, Ecke Forstweg  13_36  VOC_160123-3552 xeno.mp3
recordings.rmk: Weather: light rain after a frosty night. The bird is singing in a street tree for at least six minutes. A big garden is near, the wood in a distance from about 200 m  -  in this area it seems to breed, because I see and hear here Crossbills every day.  Very interesting is, that some passages of his song sounds for two voices. When in 1:50 the noise of an electric saw and    then an aeroplane begins, it  starts clearly to sing louder!
Breeding bird
Breeding bird
Breeding bird
The flight call of a "Type 2" Red Crossbill. Low-frequency traffic, wind, and creek sounds eliminated; higher-frequency interference from ubiquitous Broad-tailed Hummingbirds not eliminated.
4 Crossbills in the crown of  a big tree at the edge of the forest, singing, calling each other, flying. At least two females. Sunny weather. HPF to filter away the street noise.
D-type calls! (Phantom Crossbill) In my opinion pretty rare in the Netherlands.

recordings.loc: Bay Bulls, Division No. 1, Newfoundland and Labrador
recordings.rmk: This was my first success in recording the flight calls of this Newfoundland type 8 Red Crossbill. The quality is marginal as I was using my Sony PCM D-50 with built in mics rather than a directional mic. Still, I was recording from just a few feet away from a flock of ten or so birds.

Calls, chatter and song fragments of a flock of about 40 red crossbills settling in top strata of coastal forest. Warm and calm day. Low frequencies filtered to reduce the roar of the nearby sea. Recording equipment: Telinga pro 7 Dat mic, Sound devices 702.

Calls of a flock of about 40 red crossbills flying over coastal forest. Warm and calm day. Low frequencies filtered to reduce the roar of the nearby sea. Recording equipment: Telinga pro 7 Dat mic, Sound devices 702.
Bird flying over coastal wood. Warm day. Recording filtered (Low frequencies) to remove the roar of the waves. Recording equipment: Telinga Pro 7 Dat mic, sound devices 702.

recordings.loc: Eriz, Thun District, Canton of Bern

recordings.rmk: natural vocalization; both 'toop' and flight calls from a male bird perched high in a tall pine tree in selectively logged pine forest with a fairly open understory.  The last few calls given in flight.
flock of 5 birds

recordings.loc: Pike National Forest (near  Woodland Park), El Paso County, Colorado
recordings.type: alarm call, female, flight call, male, recordist noise, wind
recordings.rmk: Mated pair of type 5 in extensive Lodgepole Pine forest. Observed foraging for over 30 minutes primarily (~90%) on weathered (gray) serotinous cones, the other 10% of foraging on new non-serotinous cones. Pair flew up to the top of an adjacent Lodgepole and started giving alarm calls in response to pishing.

recordings.loc: Old Monarch Pass, Chaffee Co., Colorado
recordings.rmk: natural vocalization; excitement ('toop') and a few flight calls from a female type 5 individual perched near the top of a tall subalpine fir in fairly open spruce-fir forest.  Some slight noise from a nearby powerline in the background.

recordings.loc: Montaña de Izopo, Sector Las Moras
recordings.rmk: A female giving calls from a tall dead tree, perched near the top at approximately 18 m high. Halfway in the recording, a male can be heard calling, at first from afar and then equally close (perched in the same tree at more or less the same height, 5 m between them). The second half of the recording has his calls, not hers, although she was still there. His calls are similar doubled notes, but slightly lower-pitched.
